titleStmt.title: William Morris to Thomas Pennant, 23 February 1758

div.p: I should not have waited for a Reply to my November Lre, if I had been sure where another could have found you out. Nor could I have refrain'd much longer tho' in the Dark, if your kind favours of the 6th. Currt. had not appear'd, for I began to be anxious abot. your health.William Morris's letters to his brother in early 1758 show his concern regarding a lack of communication from Pennant. See his letter to Richard Morris, dated 16 January 1758 ('A wyr yr un o honoch, f'eneidiau, ddim o hanes y Bennant?'; 'Does either of you, my friends, have any tidings of Pennant?'), in ML, II, p. 61. Pennant's letter of 6 February 1758, mentioned here, is probably the one to which William refers on 13 February 1758, again writing to Richard, where he reports that 'the last post brought me a letter from Pennant' ('Y post diweddaf a ddug i'm llythyr oddiwrth y Bennant'). Ibid. brother Lewis, dated Bath is a suspicious place to be in all winter, and am sorry to find that it is unvirtuous too. Your new found Plan for a new Catalogue must be very useful as you are a draughtsman, what would I not have given to be one the last Spring tide, being at the Sea Side at low water the Greatest Ebb I have seen, Several bodies presented 'emselves which I could neither delineate nor preserve.–

What, drop all your foreign Fossil friends! Sure you'll not neglect the Good Bp of Bergen, and eke our Princely Brother of Cagliari.This is probably a reference to Ignazio Paternò-Castello, although it is surprising to see him referred to as a prince of Cagliari, which is in Sardegna rather than Paternò-Castello's native Sicily. It's well after such unwelcome news, that you Console me with the Hopes of being partaker of 3 Foreign Cargo's. May they safely Arrive say I. –William Morris's letter of 13 February 1758 to Richard does not give corroborating details of the letter he had received from Pennant, only to say that it was a very kind one ('caredigawl iawn yttyw'). See ML, II, p. 61; and note 1 above.

I am obliged to you for the return of Willoughby whose company wth. the rest of his Brethren are extreamly entertaining and instructive.On Pennant's practice of lending natural history books to William Morris, see Dafydd Wyn Wiliam, Cofiant Wiliam Morris (1705–63) (Llangefni: Yr Awdur, 1995), p. 148. Fortune hath been somewhat favourable to Virtú this last Season in the marine way. Have had the Opportunity of seeing Several Sun Fish, a White Shark A Scorpæena, a Tope, and the other Day a Large Dolphin was driven dead into this Harbour it was nigh 8½ ft. long I have some kind of Icons of them by me which shall be most humbly Submitted to my Good Preceptor when I find he is in a Tranquil State at his incomparable Musæum.–William Morris refers to Pennant's home, Downing.

I have discover'd in this Neighbourhood the Green Amiantus fibris fragilibus Diaphanis of
Linnæus, No. 3. wch. he describes thus. Constat fibris Separabilibus, rigidis, valde fragilibus instar vitri, Subpellucidis, virescentibus –See Caroli Linnæi, Systema Naturæ, 5th edn., (Lugduni Batavorum [Leiden]: Theodorum Haak, 1756), p. 162, no. 3. I do not remember to have seen it at Downing, –William Morris refers to a journey from his home in Holyhead as far as Downing, undertaken in July 1757. See 1404. The Dolphin abovementčond is the Delphs. Corpo. oblong. Subterati, rostro longo acuto of Linnæus, very uncom~on here.See Carl von Linné [Linnaeus], Systema Naturae, 5th edn., p. 77, under Delphinus, no. 2: 'D. corpore oblongo subereti, rostro attenuato acuto'. References are made to 'Art. gen. 76, fyn. 105. Syst. nat. 39. n. 2'. Pennant refers to Linnaeus's 'Delphinus Delphis' in British zoology (2nd edn., 1768–70), III, p. 48. the the ConjurerThe identity of the 'Conjurerer' is uncertain. He may possibly be identified with Siôn Owen, who collected specimens on behalf of William Morris, although it is implied here that the person in question benefitted from the work, through payment or payment in kind from Pennant. (to whom I have deliverd your Dole) had found a piece of the Jaw bone of one near Carnarvon, my Paper will contain no more Chat, I am wth. humble respects

closer.salute: Good Sir Your most obliged humble Servt

postscript.p:
P. S.
Dr. Ellis Greets you. he dont take to Virtù.
